Title:
Contribution of the COI mitochondrial DNA barcode to
characterizing the specificity of the ant (Hymenoptera, Formicidae)
fauna of a Mediterranean island
Abstract:
The mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (COI) is
the most popular DNA sequence used for barcoding the animal kingdom. We
used this marker to assess the taxonomic status of Corsican populations
of seven ant species groups that occur both on Corsica and European
mainland. (i) In one group (Camponotus aethiops and Camponotus
universitatis), we detected no genetic differentiation between Corsica
and the continent. (ii) In four groups, we detected strong genetic
differentiation between Corsica and the continent, confirming taxonomic
treatment based on morphology. For three of these four groups, Corsican
and continental populations were recently treated as distinct species
(Temnothorax mediterraneus and Temnothorax continentalis, Lasius
casevitzi and Lasius paralienus, Lasius emarginatus). For the fourth
group (Temnothorax unifasciatus), we proposed to raise the status of
Corsican populations from sub-species to species : Temnothorax cordieri
stat.rev. (iii) In one group, we considered the genetic differentiation
and the morphological differences did not support splitting, and thus,
we proposed the following synonymy: Temnothorax tuberum = Temnothorax
melanocephalus syn.nov. (iv) In the last group (Myrmica scabrinodis and
Myrmica spinosior), Corsican populations formed two clades genetically
distant from continental populations, but these two clades did not match
morphological distinction of the species. In addition, our analysis led
us to propose the following synonymy: Myrmica scabrinodis = Myrmica
martini syn.nov. Although COI presents many drawbacks, it should be used
more often as a complement to morphological taxonomy.
